title: 10 ways to make a good first impression in business
text:

Tue, Sep 8, 2015, 18:00 BST - UK Markets closed 10 ways to make a good first impression in business By Rebecca Burn-Callander | Telegraph – 31 minutes ago 0.0001 0.0000 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) takes just seven seconds to form a first impression - make sure you use those precious moments wisely 
Business behaviourist Jez Rose offers advice to ensure your first meeting with a customer, investor or prospective employee is not your last, 
= 1. Think “likeable” = 
When was the last time you gave anything to someone that you didn’t like? Whether it’s advice, or the most valuable of our assets, time, you need to be likeable. 
= 2. Exceed expectations = 
The greatest impressions are often made when we not only meet but exceed the expectations of others. It shows we’ve put in extra effort and are more likely to be remembered. 
= 3. Consider your own experiences = 
When were you especially impressed by a first impression ? What can you learn from that? 
= 4. Start with the basics = 
Be polite, smile, make eye contact, dress smartly, be selfless and listen. 
= 5. Flattery works = 
We all enjoy being told we look nice, or are intelligent. The secret is to use flattery subtly and in context too much flattery quickly becomes uncomfortable and sometimes creepy. * 'Narcissists' perform best in job interviews according to study * Seven ways to appear more intelligent than other people = 6. Prepare = 
As Benjamin Franklin famously said: “By failing to prepare, you are preparing to fail.” Perhaps it’s a case of reading up on the people you’re going to meet , or doing some research on the location or company, or simply working out alternative routes to get there in case of traffic. 
= 7. Be on time = 
Surveys frequently show that a lack of punctuality and being kept waiting nearly always feature in the top five of lists of gripes. 
= 8. It’s not about you = 
Creating successful impressions is about understanding that it’s about the other person. There’s no time for showing off like a peacock; what are the benefits to the other person? Make it all about them. 
= 9. Find common ground = 
In interests or hobbies, or even food, for example. This subtle way of demonstrating similarities in characteristics and personalities helps to position you as someone like the other person. 
= 10. Be sympathetic to standards = 
We expect people we meet to have minimum standards of politeness and cleanliness but those standards are subjective . Consider what other people’s standards might be and adjust your own if necessary. 
Jez Rose is working with hotel group Crowne Plaza to offer advice for business travellers (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
